review_title: If you have the luxury, leave
pros: Good pay and good food
cons:
Bullied by the other staff, constantly told I had bad customer service (no complaint from other jobs I've been in before or after), got yelled at in front of customers. Pressured me to work hours I couldn't (due to caring responsibilities, established this before starting).
One member of staff felt faint one day and I told her, as it was quiet and everything had been cleaned down etc, to go and sit down and drink some water- we then both got reprimanded because there's "no sitting on the job". Was told the week after that same staff member had quit (later found out she was fired)
Eventually I was fired with no warning (was only told when I showed up for work that week that I was "still off for holidays", a blatant lie, and after two weeks of no contact I finally got a call from my recruitment agency boss to say I had been let go- couldn't even call me themselves to tell me).
There's understandably unpleasant public service jobs and then there's Starbucks, which takes it to a whole new level of horrible.

review_title: Great only if you are working at corporate
pros: Great benefits and energetic team environment
cons:
Low pay. The company is obsessed with details like dust on top of doorways or stickers being the wrong color or size. 

Very physically and mentally draining with crazy hours. At one location our start time was 4:15am.

The company rewards bad customer behavior and does little to provide safety measures against serious incidents. I reported that my district manager told me to hire more white people and nothing was done. Many problems are constantly shifted onto store managers, and the company is reluctant to discipline problematic employees (partners). When one of my employees cussed out my assistant manager, I was encouraged to not discipline the employee and that it was my fault for not recognizing the employee more. 

Every week a major rollout happens and perfect execution is demanded, regardless of any external factors (such as call offs and customer incidents).

A customer spit in my face and the company was hesitant to ban the customer. We couldn’t get locks on our restroom doors despite a gun being found and numerous dirty needles. It became a homeless hotspot for people to bathe and misuse the restrooms.

After working 50+ hours in a week, my district manager demanded I would call her if I wanted to modify my own schedule and leave early by even 15 minutes on a given day. I thought store managers would be store managers.

pros: Great work environment and team. Staff and management are respectful, patient, and supportive. Learning barista skills is fairly simple and fun. Great benefits such as insurance, financial aid, trust fund cup, bean stock, .... Also, employees are allowed a bag of coffee or a box of tea every week for free. Free drinks during shift and good discount off work. Fair amount of tips. Very flexible hours. Swapping or giving shifts is a possibility and not complicated at all. Employees are actually given a decent amount of breaks (paid and unpaid) depending on shift duration. No uniform aside from apron and hat. Clients are more respectful in general which allows you to develop your customer skills.
cons: Four star because there is always the one or two employees who do not work at all and have no respect. Management is good but sometimes neglect their responsibilities as the boss. And, yes, most clients are very nice but the ones who aren't are extremely spoiled and entitled. Rushes can be stressful at times.

review_title: Great benefits, but working at SB is a lifestyle, not just a job
pros: Lots of perks and benefits, free drinks, free coffee, stock options, funding for equipment for Starbucks employee sports teams, etc. You also work with a lot of eccentric people, which can be a lot of fun. You can also pick up some skills around coffee profiles and beverage creation.
cons: At least where I worked, the schedules were rarely consistent, you had to work a shift every weekend, and there was an environment where everyone was always on call because people were always calling out. This made it difficult to make any plans with anyone because time off was difficult to approve and you don’t know which day you’ll be off every weekend. People who didn’t commit their every waking moment to Starbucks were looked down upon from those who did. This was a trickle-down issue, the regional manager hired store managers like them, who hired shift managers like them, etc. Do some research into your local store vibes. Also, the espresso machines work by you pressing a button and espresso comes out. This means you miss out on learning how to grind, dose, and adjust espresso, skills you need for other barista jobs.

pros: Starbucks really does care for its employees, so many people have been there for years, and as time goes on Starbucks adds on more benefits. I can get Spotify for free, Headspace for free among other things. They are also paying for me to get my Bachelor's degree at ASU. Plus they hire from within, so even if you have no college degree and this is your only place of income, you have the chance to become a store manager and a district manager and their salaries are really nice. My store manager and assistant store manager really care about us, I understand that varies from store to store but overall I have loved working at Starbucks and I have met so many friends there. Plus I can have free drinks all shift long!
cons: If you end up working at a drive-through store you might be stressed out. Window times is the number one thing, along with customer satisfaction scores. You have to figure out how to be nice in about 30 seconds while handing people their drinks. There are always tasks to be done and it can seem neverending and overwhelming, but at the end of the day if you have a team that supports you then you'll be fine!

review_title: Fine first job, but would not recommend
pros: The only pros from working at Starbucks were that they fully trained you in the barista position which allowed finding other jobs in the field much easier, and the fact that I worked at an extremely busy location which gave me good experience in a fast paced and high stress work environment.
cons: It was so corporate based the whole time I worked there. Our store's top priority was to have better numbers and faster times than the other local stores, rather than taking our time and producing better products. I was in high school when working this position and repeatedly asked for a schedule change as I was unable to work the times they put me down for with my school hours, but they were not changed, and I was reprimanded more than once for coming late to shifts even though I was 17 and still in school. I personally really disliked working at Starbucks as it's such a big comapany that I don't think they truly value employees like they should.

review_title: Fun atmosphere, nice perks, bad pay
pros: You get a couple good perks working part time. I'm reluctant to call them benefits because I got negligible vacation and no insurance etc. A pound of coffee a week, a sandwich/wrap as a meal, free drinks while you work.
cons:
Pay was awful. They try and treat you like "partners" and not employees (you get a small amount of stock the longer your work). People tip, but the tips vary greatly based on where you are. If your store is slow in a nice area, you dont have to split with many employees and you get good tips. If you're at a busy store they will have more people on staff, you'll work harder, and get much fewer tips. 

There was a big push to get payed more and starbucks created a campaign within the company to show that they cared and that they would help their struggling employees. I think I got bumped from $8.25 to $8.50 after working there for 5 years.

review_title: I used to love it, but would never go back.
pros:
- Love the people, most customers, and delicious drinks!
- Low pay, but good benefits.
cons:
- Corporate creating weekly "BOGO"s but due to labor measures, we were constantly understaffed. This kept us under stress at all times.
- Criticized if needing to call off; as sometimes two people are all that is scheduled for a few hours & have a rule of never working alone. 
- Forcing the idea of "third place" to the customers, and corporate only relying on surveys given to some customers. If you were scored 6/7 for a category (speed, accuracy, cleanliness, home-like atmosphere, and whether we upsold or not), you failed for that survey and 7/7 was the expectation. Therefore, if it was not the best coffee someone had, and did not want to rate it a 7/7, we were yelled at.

pros:
* Lots of room for improvement within position
* Working bar (making drinks) is fun, challenging
* Getting familiar with repeat customers is rewarding
* LGBTQ employees are welcome, though there are some equity issues that could be improved
* Free drinks, food discounts
cons:
* Corporate frequently introduces new drinks and such which completely screw up the very tight workflow
* Staffing constantly being cut to the detriment of productivity
* Benefits are great, but you'll have a hard time making the 20-hour requirement since staffing is constantly being cut
* Inconsistent hours
* No protection from abusive customers (the company seems to have a policy of never permanently banning people from stores)
* No room for shift leads to become managers; hiring always seems to come from outside the company
* Shift leads/managers will take their frustration out on you and you'll just have to "fake it until you make it" as per the instructions given to staff... If you struggle with mental health, you will be punished for it
* Minimum wage is just simply too low a pay for work this demanding and emotionally draining
* Was literally lied to about health benefits that are only available in the States

pros: Flexible hours, great benefits, decent pay
cons: It’s customer service. For better or for worse, you are a corporate cog and you realistically have very little input. You deal with difficult customers often and are usually forced to just deal with being walked all over. This, of course, varies based upon your manager or the level of abuse you’re subjected to, but usually Starbucks customers are rewarded for their petulant behavior due to the policy of Starbucks to “make it right” for the customer. This is more so a gripe about customer service and less about Starbucks specifically, but I found myself having to take lots of crap from lots of people and not being able to really do a thing about it.

review_title: Meh Minimum Wage Job, But Not the Worst
pros:
- Free drinks/food 30 min before, during, and 30 min after your shift
- Free Spotify premium as a benefit
- 30% discount on anything w/ your partner numbers
- Affiliate discounts (varies)
- Paid Time Off (PTO)
- Parental leave
- Discounted company stock
- Weekly bag of coffee beans/tea markout (free)
- Good if you need a job right now
- Some stores, depending on management, will allow u to use your partner free drink/food, even if you don't work at that particular store (they're not supposed to)
- They have healthcare if you need it but you need to work so many hours within 3 months to be eligible
- They have a 401(k) plan w/ company match called 
- They have the free undergraduate degree program though Arizona State University, which can be extended to a family member if you're a veteran
- If you don't want to switch careers, it is very possible to go from barista -> certified barista trainer -> shift supervisor/manager -> store manager.
- This certainly isn't worst job you could have, but it definitely won't be the best either.
cons:
- Minimum wage
- Very high turnover
- People call out all the time and you will most likely be doing a lot more work than you should every shift (this is not the company's/management's fault though)
- Customers can be downright abusive sometimes, but don't expect management to do anything about it even if they see it. Even when I was berated by customers, my shift supervisors got upset and were going to say something, but my store manager came over and said, "No, everything is fine. It's not a big deal". 
- "Customer Connection Score" comes above all. Above you taking your break. Above you leaving on time. In the case of COVID, often above your personal safety.
- It doesn't matter how hard you work and how much you sacrifice, in terms of actual raises it goes by how long you've been there (supposedly) but they never actually give raises unless your position changes. They view the state's MANDATED minimum wage hike as your raise they gave you.
- Remember, no matter how friendly management is towards you, they are not your friend. They are not your acquaintance. They are your boss, period.
- Has to be reiterated because it's important you understand: CUSTOMERS CAN BE ABUSIVE (typically verbally, rarely physically).

pros:
- One free meal and multiple free drinks on both shift, and one free drink and discount meals off shift.
- Good medical coverage (in health, dental, and vision)  if you work 20+ hours and after 3 months. 
- Have a College Achievement Plan where you can go to college for free if you work 20+ hours.
- Free Spotify.
- Lyra, a mental help app, even if it’s kind of useless. 
- If you absolutely LOVE Starbucks and don’t mind the horrible treatment on employees, because you just absolutely LOVE Starbucks over your own self-worth. This job is for you.
cons:
- TERRIBLE. MANAGEMENT. IN. MOST. IF. NOT. AALLLL. STARBUCKS. 
- Corporate doesn’t care about their employees at all, and their “partners surveys” and even ethics hotline is just a facade. The company doesn’t do anything anymore to improve the morale of employees and will allow managers (especially SM) to emotionally abuse employees because the company will not stop them from power tripping. 
- The fact that you can get written up for the stupidest things. Like clocking in one minute earlier? Write up. Clocking in one minute later? Write up. Saying a word that’s not even a cuss word but sounds like one? [I.E. heck, dang, shoot, etc.]? Write up. Calling out because you’re sick and can’t come in? Write up. Customer PHYSICALLY ASSAULTS an employee by throwing a drink at them because they made it wrong? Write up, for “upsetting” the customer. For “having an attitude” because an employee wasn’t smiling (even though we have masks?) for one minutes? Write up. And the managers can get away with this because corporate simply doesn’t care so as long as they get money. 
- The training and treatment for newer barista SUCKS, because of a combinations of trainers and managers not wanting to do their jobs to teach new baristas on how to make drinks mixed in with both managers and trainers berating then for not knowing HOW to make drinks, which makes newer employees both not know or WANT to learn how to make drinks properly. 
- The pay isn’t worth dealing with the amount of mentally and physically stress that employees (and personally me) would have to go through everyday, due to the fact that Starbucks literally creates an environment that customers can treat the employees however they want because of how the company will refuse to defend their employees from any forms of harassment.
- Lack of good management that can handle criticism nor is willing to try to make a work place environment better. Most Starbucks stores I’ve worked at have this “it’s my way or the highway” mentality where both DM, SM, or even some SSV refuse to accept valid criticism, and will degrade employees for making suggestions to improve the workplace.
- Not to mention the contradictory goals that corporate would force employees to try to achieve. Not, we can’t have fast order time AND do customer connections at the same time. It’s impossible. 
- Finally, just the absolute cult-like mindset that some Starbucks employees (especially management) has. Yes, Starbucks offers better benefits than most companies, but it’s not the GREATEST company ever and people who can see problems shouldn’t be bullied into not pointing them out just because they don’t want to accept that Starbucks is anything less than “perfect.”

review_title: Highly stressful environment with high expectations
pros: healthcare if qualified, queer friendly environment, diverse, fun if you like fast paced work, ASU undergrad degree payed for if you qualify, tips can be decent if you work in a busy area, mostly flexible hours, it's usually not too difficult to get complaints addressed, lots of room for a change of pace, easy to transfer locations, store managers typically want to make sure everyone is content and they encourage good communication. In my experience, Starbucks has offered me decent accommodations for my disabilities. Store managers encourage partners to focus on their health and offer support. There are many hidden benefits: free Spotify premium, good healthcare, discounts on many products and services, free coffee and food, access to mental health care in the form of 20 free therapy visits per year, access to lawyers, access to support in case of disaster/ major life events.
cons: Starbucks is focused on customer experience and profits in a very negative way. Customers are not to be called out for treating workers poorly. Partners are overworked to the point of mental and physical exhaustion. This is a surprisingly high-demand job. Upper management is very focused on "time" especially in drive thru stores, meaning they force workers to work very efficiently, leaving no room for error or genuine connection with customers. Partners are watched very closely using the data collected surrounding timing and profit. They are praised or confronted depending on their time efficiency and profit. Partners are forced to please customers to the point where there is a lot of room for mistreatment. I don't know a single employee who has not been pushed to the point of pretty heavy mental exhaustion. I've cried and seen many people cry at work due to the stress of the environment. Managers are prone to favoritism. For example, I am an adult who pays rent and has pretty high expenses and I get less hours than 16 year olds who have very few personal expenses, due to favoritism. I am losing my healthcare shortly because I lessened my hours at work a while back due to the temporary worsening condition of my illness. So... losing the healthcare that I heavily rely on to prevent myself from extreme pain and possible organ failure... because I needed to lessen my hours to help my body heal from a temporary worsening of my condition. Upper management (district and above) has no clue what it's like to work in the environment that they have so much control over. They push workers harder than should be possible and they make major changes that are a massive pain to all workers below them. This is a very taxing job and it's not as easy as it looks. It takes a lot of focus, hard work, and mental energy. I feel that Starbucks is on its way out unless upper management makes some major adjustments for the better of its employees.

review_title: Okay as a first job for teens, if you value autonomy and being seen as an adult human being don't bother.
pros:
Worked reasonable hours and employee discount. 
Free drinks on shift. 
Opportunities to develop customer service skills,
Some friendly regulars
cons:
Disjointed management. Out of touch and robotic area management.
Manager vaping in the office and whilst checking food fridges,
Belittled by management for not knowing brand new drinks recipes the day they came out only for the person belittling to not know it themselves next shift. 
Managers poor attitude rubbed off on the team, no motivation.
So much trickle down pressure to constantly increase profits to unrealistic levels and at the cost of employee mental health and job satisfaction. It made staff retention horrible and people were constantly leaving after only working a few months and in some instances, weeks. We struggled to have time to clean when staff numbers were being reduced to increase profit, so the café often got so messy customers would complain to area management who then complained we weren't cleaning- whilst we had two staff, one on till and one frantically making drinks all whilst a queue of 20+ people snaked outside the door. 
Often that lead to having an extortionate amount of cleanup at the end of the day. Which lead to supervisors secretly clocking staff out early so we weren't paid whilst we stayed and cleaned the mess, which is wage theft. The clocking out started happening after supervisors started having meetings with area management. We were being exploited for a billion dollar companies profit.

pros: You will meet interesting customers. You will connect with amazing co-workers. Free drinks are a plus. When you have a good shift manager, you'll have a good day. The overall environment when you're not on the clock definitely feels like a second home. Opening and Closing shifts are pretty fun once you get into a routine.
cons: The pay is ridiculously low for the amount of work you put in. If you have a bad shift manager, you will have a bad time. Morning shifts are the absolute worst but a lot of the times, different shifts will be pitted against each other throughout the day because shift managers run things differently from one another. Corporate meetings are essentially useless because district managers will never listen to concerns from the workers. Before Corona, you will have also encountered some customers who will constantly try to violate your personal space. If they are regulars, some managers will let it slide because they will let the district manager know about their experiences at your shop. The scheduling is pretty bad, as you will often be called on your off day to come in because someone decided to not show up, or the store didnt anticipate crazy rushes. Rushes will break the morale of any store despite great teams a store might have because any hiccup will destroy the momentum and cause teams to turn on one another.

job_title: Store Manager in White Center, WA
pros: Great job for a great company with a soul. Excellent benefits, stock options, and 3 weeks vacation for new managers in addition to sick time, 2 personal days a year (paid) and paid holiday option (extra vacation day if you work tue holiday). Company really cares about the employee and tons of career advancement opportunities particularly if you live in the Seattle area. Also college degree program for all employees without contract or limit of majors. Also since it is such a large company, moving and transferring to different regions in the country is fairly easy and commonly done.
cons: As a manager, your schedule will be all over the place. You will need to work some weekends. It is a lot to learn as an external hire and the success rate of externally hired managers is not super high unless you are very familiar with the food industry. You get paid salary for a job and however many hours it takes you to do that job is what you are expected to work. That usually never results in a 40 hour work week. If you are either a new manager or a manager who is trying to promote to a higher position, you will be putting in 50-60 hours a week. Also you must he on call as the sole manager in most stores so work life balance is not really respected. When I was managing a store, if I was going to be out of cell phone range on my days off (for instance if I was camping, hiking, ect.), I would have to get another manager to "proxy" my store to take calls while I was out. It is a good job and a great company but get ready to never really get to "clock out".
